did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill: Michael McCarthy records, 1970-1998.
did.physdesc: Correspondence, preliminary design work drawings, slides, photographs, blueprints, a model, publicity and promotional materials.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Correspondence, preliminary design work drawings, slides, photographs, blueprints, a model, publicity and promotional materials relating to Michael McCarthy's partnership in the New York office of the firm.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Michael A. McCarthy’s career as an architect spanned more than four decades and produced a wide variety of buildings for corporate and institutional clients. He also worked on interior design projects as well as preservation and rehabilitation projects for buildings belonging to, both, recent and historic past. McCarthy also served on art advisory committees, most notably that of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

Michael Anthony McCarthy was born on July 15, 1934 in Buffalo, New York. In 1957, he received the Bachelor of Architecture degree at Cornell University, where his fifth-year thesis project won accolades. In 1957, he worked briefly for the firm Harbach and Clark. Upon graduation he was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the Army and chose to do active duty in the Far East, where he visited places such as Korea, Japan, Hong Kong, Hawaii, and Macau. After completing his army service, he was granted the Eidlitz Fellowship, an award administered by the Department of Architecture at Cornell. He then worked for three years for Foit and Baschnagel, until 1963, when he received the license to practice architecture in New York State, and became a member of the American Institute of Architects. He received his M.Arch. degree in 1964 from Graduate School of Design at Harvard University.

In the autumn of 1964, McCarthy was hired by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill (SOM), a leading architectural firm credited with iconic modernist works. McCarthy’s work as a Junior Designer for the Gordon Bunshaft designed headquarters of the American Can Company in Greenwich, Connecticut led to his promotion to Participating Associate in 1967, and to Partner in 1973. Worldwide, McCarthy has designed mixed-use, office, residential, and recreational complexes for sites in Europe, the Far East, the Middle East, and Latin America. His awareness of and sensitivity to cultures outside the United States were particularly notable in the Middle East, where he designed interiors for the Joint Banking Center, the Commercial Bank of Kuwait, the Al Ahli Bank in Kuwait, and the National Commercial Bank of Saudi Arabia in New York, among others. His work for the Chase Manhattan Bank, which he considers as among the most rewarding and satisfying experiences of his career, consisted of designs for new buildings as well as significant contributions to the style and experience of their interiors, both through his own designs and by serving on their art committee. Over the course of his career, he also contributed to the interior designs of corporate clients, such as General Electric, Texaco, IBM, and Chrysler. McCarthy’s work with SOM has won many honors and awards.

He served on the Cornell University Council and the College of Architecture’s Advisory Council endowed a Chair of Architectural Theory at the Cornell University College of Architecture, Art, and Planning; and gifted to the Cornell University Library of the drawings, slides, photographs, and other related materials documenting his career as an architect He regarded the gift of his papers to Cornell as one of the most important contributions he has made to architectural education. He also provided a research fund for use of the collection by students and scholars.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, preliminary design work drawings, slides, photographs, blueprints, a model, publicity and promotional materials relating to Michael McCarthy's partnership in the New York office of the firm. Major projects include: the Islamic Cultural Center, New York; Megaworld Place and Petron Megaplaza in Manila; Pratt Institute Master Plan and Residential Center; Transitional Housing for the Homeless, New York; Commercial Bank of Kuwait; Beijing Mixed Use Developments, Banque Bruxelles; General Electric Corporate Headquarters, Fairfield Connecticut; and the Greenville-Spartanburg Airport.

did.unittitle: Series VII. Architectural Projects, Commissions, and Built Works, 1964-1998 (SOM Years)
9 West 57th Street - 1166 Avenue of the Americas projects

scopecontent.p: Gordon Bunshaft, design partner

9 West 57th is a 49-story travertine and glass tower with a unique sloping base. Renovations were first made to Sheldon Solow's suite in 1981 - 1983. In 1994 - 1997, renovations were also made to Mr. Solow's suite and garage.

did.unittitle: Project description, specifications, project personnel roster, meeting minutes, correspondence, and newspaper clippings.
61 Broadway (Winthrop Financial Corporation / First Winthrop), New York

scopecontent.p: Renovation of a lobby and first four floors of the facade of a building originally designed by Francis Kimball in 1914. Changes also included a new limestone facade and entrance loggie more in keeping with the building's original Beaux Arts character. Winner of the 1988 Tucker Award

did.unittitle: Project summary, location map, awards application, materials catalog, newspaper clippings, and published articles

scopecontent.p: Renovation of a lobby and first four floors of the facade of a building originally designed by Francis Kimball in 1914. Changes also included a new limestone facade and entrance loggie more in keeping with the building's original Beaux Arts character. Winner of the 1988 Tucker Award
Roy O. Allen, design partner
Renovations, Goldman, Sachs Trading Room, 1992 - 1994

did.unittitle: 570 Lexington Avenue (General Electric Building), New York

scopecontent.p: The restoration of the facade of this historic 1920s-era Art Deco building included replacement or preservation of fenestration, cleaning and replacement of brickwork in an array of special shapes and colors, and terra-cotta details in accordance with guidelines established by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1987. The project also included interior renovations and a dramatic lighting of the tower top, giving the General Electric Building a distinctive outline on the Manhattan skyline.

did.unittitle: Project summary, list of subcontractors, published articles, and awards applications
American Institute of Architects New York Chapter 1993 Design Award for Preservation; New York State Association of Architects Citation for Design (1993)

757 Third Avenue (Winthrop Financial Corporation / First Winthrop), New York

scopecontent.p: Redesign of the lobby of a 1961 building by Emery Roth & Sons. The new design features rich decorative marbles and a hemispherical dome with indirect lighting. Also included in the project were tenant floor modifications of the 33-story office building

Alexander & Alexander, Avenue of the Americas, New York

scopecontent.p: The headquarters of this major international insurance brokerage/management consulting firm occupy one floor of the Celanese Building. This was an interior design project, including the selection of nearly one hundred original works of art from around the world.

did.unittitle: American Can Company Headquarters, Greenwich, Connecticut

scopecontent.p: Gordon Bunshaft, design partner
Roger Radford, senior designer
Michael A. McCarthy, junior designer

This corporate headquarters in a suburban setting is a reinforced concrete structure placed across a ravine so that a terraced podium connects the high ground on each side, from which rises a main office building of three stories with a large central court and a one-story executive building. Service floors and parking are below the podium, resulting in the minimum possible change to the character of the original site. Sasaki, Dawson & DeMay were the landscape architects.

scopecontent.p: SOM was chosen as the leader of a four-firm Urban Design Concept Team to investigate and attempt to mitigate the community disruption that occurs as a result of freeway constructions. SOM was specifically responsible for management of urban design, planning, highway aesthetics, and landscaping.

SOM Project #6256

Originally designed by Gordon Bunshaft of SOM in 1956, the current project included a new wing and link added to the Banque Lambert, creating an H-shaped plan with gardens in newly designed courtyards. The addition includes trading floors, an auditorium, and parking.

did.unittitle: Chase Manhattan Bank, Operations Center (Chase Financial Services Center, Metrotech, Brooklyn, New York

scopecontent.p: The major operations center for the bank, Chase Metrotech consists of a two building complex whose large lower floors act as a podium for the slender 23-story tower. The simple geometric forms and the use of such detailing as corbelled brick corners respond sympathetically to the character of the neighboring 19th-century landmarked houses. At the same time, the backlit tower distinguishes the complex on the Brooklyn skyline.

did.unittitle: General Electric Company Corporate Headquarters, Fairfield, Connecticut

scopecontent.p: Ray O. Allen, design partner
Michael A. McCarthy, senior designer
1986-1988 Courtyard and podium restored
1981-1982 Physical fitness facility
1981-1983 Corporate guest facility,
SOM Project #1210

The GE Corporate Headquarters includes two three-story buildings constructed around landscaped interior courts. The Physical Fitness Facility is located in the original headquarters complex, and includes exercise, aerobic, track, and medical facilities, lockers, a lounge, and administrative offices. The Guesthouse is a four-level facility located west of the preexisting headquarters complex, and comprises 26 guest rooms and a conference center with meeting rooms and dining facilities.

did.unittitle: IBM Customer Service Center Prototype Armonk, New York
Islamic Cultural Center of New York, East 96th-97th Streets and Third Avenue New York, New York

scopecontent.p: SOM Project #6081

The Islamic Cultural Center of New York comprises a 1,000-person mosque, an assembly room, and minaret (the latter designed by the architectural firm of Swanke Hayden Connell). It was the first religious center built for New York’s Muslim community and, with its minaret and copper-clad, precast dome, creates a striking presence in its Upper East Side community. The building is rotated on its site to face Mecca, breaking out of the city street grid. SOM’s original master plan also called for an administrative building containing classrooms, a library, offices, a conference hall, an apartment for the Imam, and a 20-car parking garage(unbuilt).

did.unittitle: RFP, alternate locations study, and correspondence.

scopecontent.p: A mixed-used structure including offices, a hotel, residential space, and parking. Two versions of this project were prepared for the client. The second scheme represents a complete rethinking of the design based on the constraint that the client was unable to obtain the land needed to build the first scheme. Consequently, the entire program was consolidated into one building instead of two.

scopecontent.p: 1987 Master plan for the Institute’s development to the year 2000 to accommodate 2,000 resident students. Leo J. did.unittitle: Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation (RCBC) Office Building, Ayala Avenue, Manila, Philippines

scopecontent.p: The RCBC Project includes development of a full block in the Makati section of Manila. Two towers rest on a two-story common podium containing branch banks, restaurants, a food court, retail facilities, health club, and 500-seat auditorium. The owner’s tower overlooks a “garden in the sky.” The project also includes a museum, theater, and “Galleria.”
